displaytitle: Qu’est-ce que c’est donc que ces chiens qui ont leur muselière pendue au cou ? (Why is it that those dogs have their muzzles hanging around their necks?), page 120 from Le Charivari, Actualités.
dimensions:
image: 24 x 21
sheet: ca. 43 x 29.3 cm.

titles.title: Qu’est-ce que c’est donc que ces chiens qui ont leur muselière pendue au cou ? (Why is it that those dogs have their muzzles hanging around their necks?), page 120 from Le Charivari, Actualités.

makers.displaymaker: Stop (Louis Pierre Gabriel Bernard Morel-Retz), French, 1825–1899

texts.textentryhtml: This print resulted from public dismay at the dissolution of the Second Empire of Napoleon III, and the establishment of the French Third Republic in 1870. In Stop’s print, visitors to the annual salon admire a painting of two dogs. One patron inquires as to why the dogs are not muzzled, to which the other responds,"Madame, it is an allegory, representing political caricature." This composition offers insight into the relationship between academic art and the more ephemeral art found in mass media; many caricaturists were formally trained and also exhibited at the salons.

displaymaker: Stop (Louis Pierre Gabriel Bernard Morel-Retz), French, 1825–1899
caption: Stop (Louis Pierre Gabriel Bernard Morel-Retz) (French, 1825–1899), Qu’est-ce que c’est donc que ces chiens qui ont leur muselière pendue au cou ? (Why is it that those dogs have their muzzles hanging around their necks?), page 120 from Le Charivari, Actualités., after 1871. Lithograph. Gift of Stephen Spector (ui.2012.1749)
